review.title: Context-Aware Hypergraph Construction for Robust Spectral Clustering
review.abstract: Spectral clustering is a powerful tool for unsupervised data analysis. In this paper, we propose a context-aware hypergraph similarity measure (CAHSM), which leads to robust spectral clustering in the case of noisy data. We construct three types of hypergraph---the pairwise hypergraph, the k-nearest-neighbor (kNN) hypergraph, and the high-order over-clustering hypergraph. The pairwise hypergraph captures the pairwise similarity of data points; the kNN hypergraph captures the neighborhood of each point; and the clustering hypergraph encodes high-order contexts within the dataset. By combining the affinity information from these three hypergraphs, the CAHSM algorithm is able to explore the intrinsic topological information of the dataset. Therefore, data clustering using CAHSM tends to be more robust. Considering the intra-cluster compactness and the inter-cluster separability of vertices, we further design a discriminative hypergraph partitioning criterion (DHPC). Using both CAHSM and DHPC, a robust spectral clustering algorithm is developed. Theoretical analysis and experimental evaluation demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed algorithm.

sections.heading: 3.1 Data description and implementation details
sections.text: In the experiments, we evaluate the proposed PKO + HSC on seven sets of data showing the basic truths for classification and clustering tasks. Detailed configurations of these data sets are presented as follows: the first dataset is the ORL facial image of 38 individuals under different images; it includes 400 facial images of 40 people, and each person has 10 images; the second dataset is a subset of the YaleB facial dataset2, and contains 2432 images of 38 individuals under different images; for computational convenience, all facial images from the two datasets are resided at 32 × 32 pixels; the third dataset is a subset of the US Postal Service (USPS) handwritten digit dataset3, and consists of 9298 16 x 16 handwritten digit images from ten clusters; the fourth dataset is a subset of the MNIST handwritten digit dataset4, representing 28 x images.

sections.heading: 3.2 Competing algorithms
sections.text: We are comparing the proposed PKO + HSC with several representative spectral clustering algorithms. These spectral clustering algorithms were recently proposed and have significant implications for the clustering community. To verify the effect of different hypergraph components, we are comparing the proposed PKO + HSC with PK + HSC (pair + kNN hypergraph spectral clustering) and PO + HSC (pair + over-clustering hypergraph spectral clustering). In fact, PK + HSC and PO + HSC are special cases of the proposed PKO + HSC with different configurations of (α, β) hyperpersimility. To evaluate the performance of different hypergraph spectral clustering criteria, we are making a comparison between DSSC and the defined PO + HSC similarity (measured by our hyperpersimility).

sections.text: For a quantitative comparison, we introduce two evaluation criteria - NMI (normalized mutual information) and the accuracy of clustering. sections.heading: 4 CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In this work, we have proposed a context-sensitive hypergraph similarity measurement (CAHSM) based on three types of hypergraphs - paired hypergraphs, k-nearest-neighbor (kNN) hypergraphs, and high-order over-clustering hypergraphs. These hypergraphs capture paired, neighborhood, and local grouping information about vertices. By effectively combining these types of affinity information, CAHSM is able to effectively capture the intrinsic structural information about vertices, resulting in robust cluster performance. To fully capture cluster compactness and separation between clusters of vertices, we have also designed a discriminatory hypergraph partition criterion (DHPC) that is solved by traceratio-maximization. Based on both CAHSM and DHPC, a robust spectral cluster formation is likely.
